symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Hypoglycemia is a common occurrence in patients managing their diabetes with insulin or certain medications.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities. It can lead to physical symptoms and could co-occur with depression.

diagnoses.name: Oral Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that causes swelling and irritation in the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes. Leukoplakia could be confused with or related to lichen planus in the oral cavity.

diagnoses.name: Anorexia Nervosa
diagnoses.description: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight or shape. Anorexia can lead to decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, depression, and sensitivity to cold.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, often causing gastrointestinal symptoms, malnutrition, and unexplained weight loss or decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of their hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, muscle weakness, decreased appetite, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex chronic condition characterized by extreme tiredness or fatigue which doesn't go away with rest and can't be explained by an underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Oral Cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that develops in the tissues of the mouth or throat. Symptoms might include a sore that doesn't heal, a lump, or a white patch (leukoplakia) on the inside of the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to osteopenia due to impaired bone mineralization, and may also manifest with muscle weakness or hyperactivity in rare cases. Folliculitis can be more common in individuals with weakened immune function, potentially linked to vitamin deficiency.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Allergic reactions can cause a variety of symptoms including irritated eyes and laryngitis due to swelling and irritation of the mucous membranes. Certain allergens may also exacerbate skin conditions, leading to folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hyperthyroidism can cause increased metabolic rates leading to hyperactivity, and its impact on calcium regulation could contribute to osteopenia. Skin conditions such as folliculitis might be observed due to changes in skin texture and immunity.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: Atopic dermatitis is a condition that can lead to irritated eyes and can be associated with secondary skin infections such as folliculitis. It is commonly linked with other allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: Contact dermatitis, while primarily affecting the skin, can cause irritated eyes if allergens come into contact with the eye area. It could also potentially contribute to skin conditions like folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Some autoimmune disorders can cause a broad spectrum of symptoms, including hyperactivity (as a result of systemic inflammation), osteopenia (due to inflammation and potential malabsorption), and skin issues like folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: Chronic stress can manifest physically as hyperactivity and contribute to skin conditions like folliculitis due to changes in immune function. Stress can also exacerbate conditions like osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Environmental Factors
diagnoses.description: Exposure to certain environmental factors like pollutants or irritants can lead to laryngitis and irritated eyes. Additionally, these factors can sometimes exacerbate skin conditions like folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalances
diagnoses.description: Hormonal imbalances, particularly those involving thyroid and parathyroid hormones, can result in symptoms like osteopenia and hyperactivity. Skin conditions such as folliculitis might also be more prevalent in the context of hormonal changes.

diagnoses.name: Seasonal Allergies
diagnoses.description: Seasonal allergies can cause symptoms such as irritated eyes and laryngitis due to allergic rhinitis. Skin manifestations such as folliculitis can occur but are less common.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, which could explain the combination of symptoms due to their systemic nature, affecting multiple organs and systems.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.description: Specifically, hyperthyroidism is mentioned, but these symptoms could also be indicative of other thyroid imbalances or complications.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues, which might relate to muscle pain and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic fatigue syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, potentially overlapping with some of the mentioned symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues, which could explain the wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal disorders
diagnoses.description: Given the mention of ulcers, conditions affecting the gastrointestinal tract that could cause ulcers and potentially relate to other symptoms due to systemic inflammation or malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Mitochondrial disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases caused by dysfunction of the mitochondria, which could result in a wide array of symptoms affecting multiple systems, including muscle pain and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Neurological disorders
diagnoses.description: Certain conditions affecting the brain, spine, and the nerves that connect them. Symptoms such as blepharospasm might be indicative of underlying neurological issues.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which can mimic many of the listed symptoms, such as muscle pain and neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the body's moisture-producing glands. While primarily known for causing dry eyes and mouth, it can also result in systemic symptoms.

diagnoses: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Contact Dermatitis or Eczema (due to allergic reactions)
Anisakiasis (due to ingestion of raw fish)
Neurodegenerative Diseases (such as Parkinson's disease or Huntington's disease)
Metabolic Disorders (such as Vitamin B12 deficiency)
Infectious Diseases (such as Neurosyphilis or Lyme disease)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may manifest as transient visual, sensory, language, or motor disturbances. Phonophobia, or sensitivity to sound, is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include numbness, trouble speaking (aphasia), and other impairments.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', it’s characterized by temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing short-lived symptoms similar to a stroke, such as aphasia and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including numbness, speech difficulties (aphasia), vomiting, and sensitivity to sound.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system. Symptoms can vary widely and include numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, partial or complete loss of vision, and slurred speech.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include vomiting, fever, confusion, seizures, and sensitivity to light and sound, including phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Some forms can manifest in symptoms similar to those described.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Symptoms may include a sudden severe headache, vomiting, loss of consciousness, and sometimes localized numbness or speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, vomiting, confusion, seizures, and sensory or motor deficits, such as aphasia or numbness.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, imbalance, and, in severe cases, localized numbness or weakness.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Cancer (e.g., Metastatic Cancer causing Pleural Effusion or Bone Marrow involvement leading to Leukopenia)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
